heptarchy.name: Saxon Kingdoms of the Heptarchy (600-700 AD)

ceorl.name: Ceorl Militia
ceorl.description: A band of freemen/ceorls (Pronouced Churls), typically made up of the conquered peoples living within the lands of a Saxon/Angles king, warlord, or noble. Even before the Anglo-Saxon traditions of a trained militia, there was the practice of the 'hundradeflocc' as recorded by the Romans. Reportively a German noble was required to provide a hundred 'picked' men to form a militia, during emergencies or to add extra numbers in times of war.

lowborn_spear_levy.name: Peasant Spear Levy
lowborn_spear_levy.description: Due to the plentiful supply of landless men, spears, and shields; it is likely that if the Saxons were involved in a battle that required them to defend their lands, rather then raid those of another, they would attempt to form a basic spear levy as was common at the time. Indeed the Romans recorded 'Germanic' people as having a practice known as the 'hundradeflocc'. Reportively a German noble was required to provide a hundred 'picked' men to form a militia, during emergencies or to add extra numbers in times of war. Such troops would have to be 'bullied' into a formation, and even if trained at all, weren't trained very well.

skirmishers.name: Landless Skirmishers
skirmishers.description: A band of the impoverished, landless men who could only bring the clothes on their back, a short blade or club, and some ranged weapons.

light_geoguth.name: Light Geoguth Warriors
light_geoguth.description: A band of Geoguth (Pronouced Yoo-Guths), was the young men and boys of a warband. Typically these men followed less experienced leaders, warlords, and chieftains

heavy_geoguth.name: Geoguth Spearmen Warriors
heavy_geoguth.description: A band of Geoguth (Pronouced Yoo-Guths), was the young men and boys of a warband. Typically these men followed less experienced leaders, warlords, and chieftains

saxon_keel.name: Saxon Geoguth Keel
saxon_keel.description: A Saxon 'Keel' is a collection of light raiders, with 'keel' being the name of the ship and the unit being the number of men to man such a ship. As expected the various 'low-life's that make up a keel, are effectively like pirates or vikings. They show up on a galley they row, they attack, they fight, and then they rob and kill people. Like many robbers or thieves, they don't appear to be that heavily equipped. A band of Geoguth (Pronouced Yoo-Guths), was the young men and boys of a warband. Typically these men followed less experienced leaders, warlords, and chieftains

early_geoguth.name: Geoguth
early_geoguth.description: A band of Geoguth (Pronouced Yoo-Guths), was the young men and boys of a warband. Typically these men followed less experienced leaders, warlords, and chieftains

duguth_raiders.name: Duguth Keel
duguth_raiders.description: The Dugutb (pronounced Doo-gutb) were the more experienced and accomplished warriors, and like many other cultures, including other 'barbarians' and even the Romans, older men typically had better equipment, resilience, and experience. As Saxon warlords or nobles gained power and grew older, they would draw in more and more of these experienced fighters, along with having their inexperienced fighters become experienced over time.

heavy_hearthguard.name: Heavy Hearthguard
heavy_hearthguard.description: The Gedribt (pronounced Tedrict) was the Saxon lord's 'hearthguard'. These men were known to have unflinchy loyalty and were willing to do any act of cruelity or violence without thought for their 'lord'. In exchange, they are given honor, glory, respect, all the finer things in life, women, and a place by the fire. These wealthier of these men even owned and rode horses into battle.

fierce.name: Fierce
fierce.description_short: If an enemy unit in short distence (12') runs away or flees, this unit has to charge them. It gets +1 to melee when it does so
fierce.description: If an enemy unit in short distence (12') runs away or flees, this unit has to charge them. It gets +1 to melee when it does so
fierce.flavor: During the early Dark Ages, some units were exceptionally eager to 'run down' or 'run through' the enemy.

strategies.name: Shield Wall
strategies.description: All units with shields and spears equipped (light infantry not included), if that unit moved one or no times this round, and if charged or targeted by a shooting attack it gets +1 Save. This effect remains in place till the unit moves.
strategies.flavor: The bordweall (Old English for 'Shield Wall'), was a tactic and model of fighting that grew popular with the Anglo-Saxons right before or around the start of the Viking Invasion. Communities were organized into sizes that would produce a 'fyrd', which is a part time militia of freemen/ceorls, who fought shoulder to shoulder in formation.

strategies.name: Veterans
strategies.description: All units of geoguth may, once for the entire battle, choose to reroll all their dice to hit by shooting or melee. All dice must be rerolled, good or bad.
strategies.flavor: Many years of campaigning have given the late Saxon kingdoms or the early raiders a pool of hardened veterans.
